Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre

Class Fluent

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.Fluent
All Implemented Interfaces:
Expression, Logical, Simplifiable, Typed, Signed, Serializable, Comparable<Logical>
Direct Known Subclasses:
CompiledFluent, PrefixFluent
public class Fluent extends Object implements Expression, Signed
A fluent is a property of a state which can be assigned a value and whose value may change as a result of an event. A fluent is identified by its signature. The values that can legally be assigned to a fluent are determined by the fluent's type. An character's belief about a fluent is represented as a different fluent. When a fluent defines one or more characters, it means the fluent represents what the first character believes the second character believes (etc.) about the fluent.

For example, say there are two characters defined, A and B. The fluent alive(A) represents whether or not A is alive. Its type is boolean, meaning it can be true or false. If the the fluent's list of characters is {A, B}, the fluent represents whether character A believes that character B believes that A is alive.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware
See Also:

    • isValued

      public boolean isValued()
      Description copied from interface: Expression
      Tests whether or not this expression is a valued expression. A valued expression is a value or an expression which describes a value and cannot be simplified any further without knowing the current state. Valued expressions are the only kind of expression which can appear on the right side of an effect's assignment. Valued expressions include:
      • a value
      • a variable
      • a numeric fluent
      • an arithmetic expression composed only of other valued expressions
      This method returns false by default and should be overridden by expressions which are or can be valued expressions.
      Specified by:
      isValued in interface Expression
      Returns:
      true if the expression describes a value and cannot be further simplified without knowing the current state, false otherwise

    • evaluate

      public Value evaluate(State state)

      Specified by:

      Parameters:

      Returns:

      public Expression negate()
      Description copied from interface: Expression

    • toValued

      public Conditional<Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>>> toValued()
      Description copied from interface: Expression
      Returns a conditional expression whose conditions are in disjunctive normal form and whose branches are valued expressions. This method is used to simplify expressions by converting anything which is not valued into valued expressions and moving any conditionals outside of the expression. If the expression is already valued, the conditional returned should have no conditions and a single branch that is this expression.
      Specified by:
      toValued in interface Expression
      Returns:
      a conditional with conditions in disjunctive normal form and branches that are valued expressions

    • toPrecondition

      public Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>> toPrecondition()
      Description copied from interface: Expression
      Converts an expression whose type is boolean to disjunctive normal form (DNF) suitable to appear in the precondition of an event. A DNF expression is a disjunction of conjunctive clauses whose atoms are preconditions.
      Specified by:
      toPrecondition in interface Expression
      Returns:
      a disjunction of conjunctive clauses whose atoms are preconditions

    • toEffect

      public Clause<Effect> toEffect()
      Description copied from interface: Expression
      Converts an expression whose type is boolean to disjunctive normal form (DNF) suitable to appear in the deterministic effect of an event. Because effects must be deterministic, this process must result in a disjunction of no more than one conjunctive clause whose atoms are effects. Because there will only be at most one clause, that clause is returned instead of a disjunction. If no clauses would be returned (in other words, if false would be returned), the null clause is returned.
      Specified by:
      toEffect in interface Expression
      Returns:
      a conjunctive clause whose atoms are effects

    • contains

      public boolean contains(Fluent fluent)
      Tests whether the given fluent is the same as this fluent, except that its list of characters is the same as or a shorter version of this fluent's list of characters. For example, the fluent believes(A, believes(B, alive(A))) contains itself, and it contains believes(B, alive(A)), and it contains alive(A).
      Parameters:
      fluent - the fluent to test
      Returns:
      true if the given fluent is the same as this fluent but with the same or shortened list of characters, false otherwise

    • removeFirstCharacter

      public Fluent removeFirstCharacter()
      Returns a new fluent where the first (leftmost) character has been removed from characters. If there are no characters, this method returns the same fluent.
      Returns:
      a fluent with the first characters removed

    • removeLastCharacter

      public Fluent removeLastCharacter()
      Returns a new fluent where the last (rightmost) character has been removed from characters. If there are no characters, this method returns the same fluent.
      Returns:
      a fluent with the last character removed
